div.head: Propositio circa generatio caritatis
div.p:
As a declaration of the matter of charity, which affects the whole theological process, as attested by our savior that
from love of God and neighbor depends the entire law and the prophets , one proposition is posited when beginning first from generations which is this: that although the gift of created charity is not absolutely necessary for the pilgrim for reaching salvation, nevertheless according to the established course of the law it is required that this charity concur in three types of causes and in the kingdom of the mind this is principally influxive and essentially required for operating virtuously.

div.head: Rationes pro prima parte
div.p: The first part is proved when understanding that any form united to its subject is united as a mover and as united as act inhering with respect to the disposition of the form to its subject as mover, nevertheless it happens that God is able to supply its causality, for every operation of love reduces to the genus of efficient cause. Whence the Holy Spirit alone suffices to incline the soul to operate meritoriously.

In the second place, the Holy Spirit alone is able to produce the act, which is immediately produced from the mind with mediating charity, therefore with respect to the total causality which charity would have with respect to the soul the Holy Spirit alone would suffice, therefore from the part of the actions the created gift is not necessary since it is able to be supplied through the Holy Spirit.

In the third place, divine acceptance, which is an interior act, is said to be a sufficient cause for this namely that the creature reach salvation, because by the fact that God wills that a creature be worthy of eternal life, it is by that fact worthy. But the will of God does not depend on a created quality, nor does is it co-bound with some quality, since it is sufficient by itself to make a creature worthy. Therefore the Holy Spirit by itself and by its own will is able to accept a creature, and having been so disposed this will be sufficient for the pursuit of salvation.

In the fourth place, before the determination of the church, namely before it would be determined that in baptism three gifts would be infused, namely faith, hope and love, it was not evidently deduced from scripture that there is another charity besides the Holy Spirit. Therefore according to the process of Scripture there appear to be many authorities to the contrary, namely, that no gift is created, indeed there was the Holy Spirit, who operated all meritorious things in creatures, as the
Master states in distinction 17 of book 1
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 17
, which holds expressly this position. From which it appears that from thee power of God absolutely it is possible that the creature is in the state of salvation without the created gift.

div.head: Rationes pro secunda parte
div.p: The second part is proved having two principal parts.

div.head: First part for the second part: that according to the currently established law it is required that some created gifts concurs in three types of causes.
div.p: The first that according to the currently established law it is required that some created gifts concurs in three types of causes, and which is preordained in the kingdom of the mind for the causation of any good work, such that love holds the first place in the kingdom of the mind, such that it is not the case that some good act is produced that charity does not principally concur with respect to that virtuous producible act in the kingdom of the mind.

But in the first place it appears
that some created habit is required through
the Decretalem
positing that in baptism there is infused in children three gifts, faith, hope, and love

In the second place, by the reason in which faith and hope were posited as distinct created gifts, by the same reasons it should be said about charity, because every reason proving about faith and hope could be proved about charity in the same mode.

In the third place, all accidents are posited and ordered into the operations of substances, though perhaps one being reckless would be able to deny accidents, nevertheless these should be conceded for substances and their operation, therefore the soul will have proportional habits and accidents conferring to the execution of its operations, as it appears in natural things from substantial form, which has many accidents, as exercises its proper operations. Therefore with respect to meritoroius operations and acts of loving God and neighbor more noble habits and acts co-acting meritorious works are required.

In the fourth place, in the state of innocence with original justice a distinct virtue is posited rectifying the inferior powers, and it harmonizes these things with the superior powers. Therefore in the state of grace, since this is posited as a supplement to original justice, a distinct thing ought to be posited.

div.head: Secunda pars pro secunda parte
that charity is found in a threefold genus of cause
div.p:
But with respect to the other second part of the second part, namely, that charity is found in threefold genus of cause. In the first place it is proved about the formal cause, not that charity is really informing, but it has itself in the mode of a form, as
Augustine
says this is the
life of virtue , therefore charity has itself in the mode of vivifying form, to which Scripture agrees, saying
faith is dead with works
of charity, and therefore its absence is death. Therefore, charity is like a form vivifying and rectifying the operations of the will.

div.head: That charity is in the genus of material cause.
div.p:
In the second place, Blessed Gregory says
a branch does not have the vigor for good work, unless it remains in the root of charity
Gregory Hom. in Ev., 27
, in this respect that it is to vivify and assist in the pursuit of good work.

There are other authorities asserting approvingly that charity is the form of all virtues, therefore faith without charity is called unformed by all doctors, from which it appears that charity is rightly said to be the form of other virtues and is found in the genus of the material cause.

div.head: That charity is in the genus of the final cause.
div.p: Next, it appears that charity is in the genus of the final cause. This is clear from the priority of the control of the soul because a leader is not the end of the parts of the army, so charity is the end of all the virtues of the soul and that to which the other virtues are ordered in the kingdom of the soul as if subjected to the mode of a superior, in which the other virtues are ordered as the parts of the army are subjected to their prince.

In the second place, with this the
Apostle
agrees, saying, that
the end of the command is love , therefore love is the end of all operations meritorious of eternal life.

div.head: Quod caritas se habeat in genere causae efficientis
div.p: Finally, it is proved that charity is the genus of the efficient cause. This is clear because, just as acts formally generate habits, so habits concur actively in the generation of acts similar to the first acts. In this mode acts generate habits in natural things, and conversely, therefore from charity habits are generated and from these habits are generated acts similar to the first. Consequently, charity concurs actively with respect to meritorious acts.

In the second place, meritorious acts exceed the ability of the natural will, therefore in the same place the concurrence of a supernatural cause is needed, namely of charity, because if it were to concur precisely by assisting in such a way
that it did not help with the achievement of the effect, but were only to assist with the appearance of the soul, then this would seem to be in concord with the error of Pelagius, indeed it would be worse, because Pelagius does deny that charity helps the soul in the execution of its works, nevertheless he concedes that the soul without charity is able to do meritorious work. But if it is posited that charity concurs actively, it follows that it will help the soul with respect to meritorious work, which Pelagius would not have conceded.

Where it should be noted that
Augustine, in the book On nature and grace , who compares the soul to health. Whence note in the same place that the state of innocence had the health of all powers in the rule of the mind constituting the control of them. Whence the superior reason had full command in the soul and the individual powers, as was necessary, were obedient to the superior portion, but by reasons of original guilt original justice was removed, which was conserving the harmony amount the inferior powers in relation to the superior, and it its place is put cupidity, the effect of which is the opposite and contrary to the effect of original justice, such that the duty of cupidity is to draw the superior portion to obedience of the lower powers. Whence the duty of the superior portion was to contemplate spiritual and heavenly things and through its obedience to the inferior powers it is drawn toward the pursuit of earthly things unless it were liberated through love.

From which it follows that charity is the health of the soul and acts in the soul, such that the inferior powers are obedient to the superior portion or reason. But charity even add something more, think of the greater strengthening which health will be in the state of innocence.

Where it should be known that in the state of innocence, the soul by virtue of its health, though it is able to produce an act of love for God above everything, nevertheless it is not able to produce an act of love of God of the same species with that which is now elicited by a mediating charity. Whence, if one act were compared to the other, such that there became a comparison in natural things, then it is not difficult. But it is said that the soul in the state of innocence would not suffice to elicit an act of the same species with that which is proved by the will with the help of mediating charity, nor would this be sufficient in the state of fallen nature.

div.head: First corollary
That charity is evidently able to be designated for all species of virtue
div.p:
From which it follows in the first place that charity is evidently able to be designated for all species of virtue, and thus evidently for prudence, fortitude, justice, temperance, such that if suffices causally, so that it can produce an act of equal perfection and greater the virtues of this type are able to do. And this position is strengthened from the authority of
Augustine in the book De moribus ecclesiae
in which he describes individual virtues and posits charity or love for the genus in any definition of virtue, and also posits that charity is able to produce any act of virtue and in a mode more eminent than the virtues.

div.head: Second corollary
That charity is really cognition
div.p:
In the second place, it follows that charity is really cognition. This is clear because it able to immediately produce an act of prudence. but no habit is able to produce an act of prudence unless it is a cognitive habit, indeed it follows that charity is able to be called prudence, science, and wisdom. And this agrees with
scripture in I John
which says that charity is
the anointing teaching about all things
I Ioannis 2:27
.

Not it not only directs the affect, but also the practical and speculative intellect, therefore it is
anointing teaching about all things
I Ioannis 2:27

head.supplied: That in the habit of love the truth of those things that should be believed shines forth

div.p:
In the third place, it follows that in the habit of charity the truth of those things that should be believed shines forth. This is clear because charity is able to produce act for any truth, therefore this is also true for act of believing, even though from the proper order divine charity never produces an act by itself because God did not ordain that in creature charity acts without the concuring of the Holy Spirit, and also with hope and faith, which is attested by the
Apostle
because he says
without faith it is impossible to please God
Ad Hebraeos 11:6 . For with respect to its own part charity is able to produce act for things being believed as it was said, since faith is not the only cognition of things being believed, but also love.

div.head: Fourth corollary
That the facility for believing things has its origin from the intention of charity
div.p: In the forth place, it follows that the facility of believing things has its origin from the intention of charity. This is clear because, if charity is the shining of things to be believed, then the more intense it is, the more facility it gives the soul.

div.head: Fifth corollary
That charity is a medicine for the weak with respect to the difficult articles of faith
div.p: In the fifth place, it follows that charity is a medicine of the weak with respect to the difficult articles of faith, such that, if, in the matter of the Trinity, predestination, reprobation, incarnation, or others difficult articles, the soul suffers a scruple, then the soul returns to charity and it will cease its weakness because this is in this case the supreme medicine.

div.head: Sextum corollarium
Quod simplex persona caritate informata est magis virtuosa quam aliquis philosophus
div.p: In the sixth place, it follows that a simple person informed by charity is more greatly virtuous that some philosopher, likeSeneca or Socrates, if they do not have charity. This is clear because charity is any virtue in any person in a more eminent mode that the virtue would be by itself.

In the second place, this charity more extensive with respect to multitude because with respect to any object this is able to have a meritorious act. But it happens that no virtue without charity is able to have a meritorious act, indeed it is able to follows that a child newly baptized is more greatly virtuous than some philosopher, even though in children there is an impediment on account of the body with respect to producing meritorious work, though nevertheless this does not destroy the magnitude of the virtues. This is clear from the eminence of charity above all other virtues. But in a newly baptized adult there is an impediment such that they cannot produce meritorious works. because, though they have a little bit of charity, nevertheless a difficulty prevails from concupiscence, which inclines one to the opposite, and in this the inferiors powers are not fully obedient ot the superior powers.

div.head: Seventh corollary
That for any rule charity is the most fitting disposition
div.p:
In the seventh place, it follows that for any rule charity is the most fitting disposition. This is clear because for the rule of the kingdom of the soul this is most sufficient and contains all the virtues which restrain all passions. It is also sufficient for the political rule, in the first place because it is able to rule the kingdom of the mind when it is in some creature, he is well suited for political rule,
and because charity does not ask which things belong to itself and which things belong to its neighbor. Therefore this is most fitting for rule because it most greatly excludes tyranny, for the tyrant does not rule on account of the political good, but on account of
its own private good. And therefore charity is the most fitting disposition for ruling, not only the mind, but political matters, and thus charity is able to be applied both to spiritual and temporal rule.

div.head: Eighth corollary
That in political and spiritual rule it ought to attend to charity both for deliberations and any other acts.
div.p: From which in the eighth place, it follows that in political and spiritual rule one ought to attend to charity both for deliberations and any other acts. This is clear because charity is teaching every science sufficiently, and it represents things according to their proper order, such that it represents God in such a way that all things tend toward him and have an essential order.

And therefore the proper order is set forth through charity and through charity what should and should not be done appears in deliberation. From which fact it is apparent that through charity the kingdom of the soul and the political kingdom ought to be ruled.

div.head: Ninth corollary
The greatest disposition for resolving the present schism would to be have charity and to run back to it.
div.p: In the ninth place, it follows that the greatest disposition for resolving the present schism would be to have charity and to run back to it because it does not ask what is one's own, nor is it ambitious, nor does it tend to toward an abundance of others possessions.

And it would be able to be inferred that in the first place the schism of the kingdom of the soul should be resolved, then in the second place, in political matters. First the spiritual schism should be destroyed then the general because the spiritual, or schism of the soul, is near and immediate.

div.head: Tenth corollary
That every deliberate action not produced by charity and some aspect of deformity.
div.p: In the tenth place, it follows that every deliberate action not produced by charity and some aspect of deformity. This is clear because this action without charity is preordained to be inordinate and deformed, and every such action is a sin, and if it is not a mortal sin, it is a least a venial sin.

div.head: Eleventh corollary
That operations proceeding from charity either do not generate a habit or generate something it is not enough to produce the same act when charity is removed
div.p: In the eleventh place, it follows that operations proceeding from charity either generate a habit or if they were to generate something through this, the will does not produce an act when this charity is removed, such as is the case if Socrates now loves God and neighbor and produces an act of love of God and neighbor, then it is said that acts of this type either do not generate a habit or if the were to generate something, then without charity Socrates would not produce an act similar to the first ones through this lingering habit because, if this were so, it would follow that the when charity is removed the will would be able to produced acts similar to the already had acts, which is false because a habit so generated from derelict charity would not be sufficient for producing similar acts. This is clear because the will is not able unless with charity to produce similar acts to these from which the will with charity produced this habit.

div.head: Twelfth corollary

That the difficulty of knowing that one is in charity does not arise from the fact that the acquired habits produced through charitable acts produce acts similar to the first acts even when the charity has been removed.
div.p:
In the twelfth place, it follows that the difficult of knowing that one is in charity does not arise from the fact that the habits acquired through loving acts produce acts similar to the first acts even when the charity has been removed. Whence some think that if one is brought into love of God and neighbor, then this act is produced in them through mediating charity, and from this act a habit is generated which is able to produce an act of loving God and neighbor even when the charity is removed, and this act is similar to the first, though the first is produced with charity. But the complete opposite is said. However, the difficulty of knowing that one is in charity arises from the part of cupidity and bad habits
incompatible with charity and also partly from the ignorance of the relations to act. When it is the case that someone has enjoyable act or enjoying act, and nevertheless does not know that he has this, for he does not know that the act relates to itself because he is not able to have a reflexive act upon his own acts, and from this arises the difficulty of knowing that one is in charity.

div.head: Thirteenth corollary
That charity is not only the health of the soul but is an augmentation and elevation beyond the natural grade of causality
div.p: In the thirteenth place, it follows that charity is not only the health of the soul, but is an augmentation and elevation beyond the natural grade of causality because the will in the state of innocence is not able to produce an act which is now possible with the help of charity, therefore the corollary is true.

And proportionally in the matter of faith, just as there corollaries posited concerning the praise of faith, so there would be concerning the praise of charity. Whence it is thought that just as faith is an instrument of a free agent, namely the Holy Spirit and disposes itself in conformity to the first truth, so charity is a quality in the Holy Spirit a meritorious act is produced in creatures and is always in conformity to the Holy Spirit because it is impossible that charity produces an act against the law, or that the act with this mediation is elicited by the will against the standing law.

div.head: Objection
That charity will not be essentially subordinated to the first truth or the Holy Spirit.
div.p: But it is argued to the contrary and posited that God does not accept the creature were it to be the case that the charity is in creature which is in sin, namely having removed the Holy Spirit and it special assistance because the Holy Spirit and charity are united at the same time, then it would be posited that from charity the would produces an act that will not be meritorious, but crooked, but as a consequence, charity will not be essentially subordinated to the first truth or the Holy Spirit. This argument was similarly made regarding faith.
And therefore it is responded by admitting the whole case. And it is said that, though this quantity which is charity remains, nevertheless this creature would not remain in charity.

In the second place, it is said that the will would not produced an act because the activity of charity is a spiritual activity requiring the influence of the Holy Spirit and the influence of a superior being concurring with it. But it is said that the Holy Spirit is not able to act immediately and and specifically to the production of evil, therefore neither can charity since the Holy Spirit always directs charity in its operations. And therefore charity always prerequires a superior cause concurring with it, and it causality is the kind that always requires the causality of the Holy Spirit. And thus it appears that charity is not able to concur to evil in the same way as to the good.
